qas.question: What type of food was preferred in Rajasthani cooking?

answers.text: Food that could last for several days and could be eaten without heating

qas.question: Along with scarce green vegetables, what had an impact on Rajasthani cooking?
What type of snack is Rajasthan known for?
What famous dish is also known as hot garlic paste?
Vegetarian restaurants come from which Rajasthani region?
What has the scarcity of food that could last for days affected?

plausible_answers.text: both the war-like lifestyles of its inhabitants and the availability of ingredients in this arid region

qas.question: What was Bikaneri Bhujia cooking influenced by?
What concept originates from the Bikaneri Bhujia region?

plausible_answers.text: first coarsely mash the Baati then pour pure Ghee on top of it

qas.question: What is the traditional way to serve Pyaaj Kachori?

plausible_answers.text: It is served with the daal (lentils) and spicy garlic chutney

context: Rajasthani cooking was influenced by <b6_0>both the war-like lifestyles of its inhabitants and the availability of ingredients in this arid region<b6_0/>. <a0_0>Food that could last for several days and could be eaten without heating<a0_0/> was preferred. The <a1_0>scarcity of water<a1_0/> and fresh green vegetables have all had their effect on <b5_0>the cooking<b5_0/>. It is known for its snacks like <a2_0>Bikaneri Bhujia<a2_0/>. Other famous dishes include bajre ki roti (millet bread) and <a3_0>lashun ki chutney<a3_0/> (hot garlic paste), mawa kachori Mirchi Bada, Pyaaj Kachori and ghevar from Jodhpur, Alwar ka Mawa(Milk Cake), malpauas from Pushkar and rassgollas from Bikaner. Originating from <a4_0>the Marwar region<a4_0/> of the state is the concept <b7_0>Marwari Bhojnalaya, or vegetarian restaurants<b7_0/>, today found in many parts of India, which offer vegetarian food of the Marwari people. 4 Dal-Bati-Churma is very popular in Rajasthan. The traditional way to serve it is to <b8_0>first coarsely mash the Baati then pour pure Ghee on top of it<b8_0/>. <b9_0>It is served with the daal (lentils) and spicy garlic chutney<b9_0/>. Also served with Besan (gram flour) ki kadi. It is commonly served at all festivities, including religious occasions, wedding ceremonies, and birthday parties in Rajasthan. "Dal-Baati-Churma", is a combination of three different food items — Daal (lentils), Baati and Churma (Sweet). It is a typical Rajasthani dish.
